description: A small Late Iron Age sub-rectangular enclosure just to the north of two larger enclosures that seemed to have been Iron Age and Roman farmsteads on the outskirts of the small Roman town of Irchester. A hole at the centre of the small enclosure was identified as a 'tree-hole', and along with deposits of 'globular' jars, lead the researchers to identify this as a possible ritual site and the tree as the focus.
bibliography: Martyn, Blick, Brindle, and et al. “Brigstock (Northamptonshire).” The Rural Settlement of Roman Britain: an online resource, 2015. https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449.

Northamptonshire Archaeology. “Iron Age and Roman Landscapes at Victoria Park, Irchester, Northamptonshire; Excavations September 2004 to May 2005.” Archaeology Data Service, 2012. https://doi.org/10.5284/1020407.
